expand the frontier of knowledge, one must be prepared to question basic assumptions and, if need be, to slaughter some sacred cows. It is only by being able to accept changes to our basic assumptions that society can find progress.

    As we progress to the new millennium, we must be prepared to move away from our mindset and be prepared to change and perhaps give up some of our own values. The values that have served us well may not necessarily be the same values that will serve our interests for the future. The question is, are we prepared to change with time, and change more radically, if necessary?

    Thirdly, it is right that we should speak of lifelong learning and of continual training of our workers to prepare them for the demands of changing technology in the new millennium. Continual training will constantly upgrade our workers' productivity and skills and, in turn, allow them to earn a higher margin of wages and improve their quality and standard of living. As we restructure our economy by emphasising on higher valued-added products in manufacturing and services, it is important that our workers continue to be retrained and re-tooled themselves to prepare them for the challenges ahead.

    The process of training and retraining is especially important for workers who have been retrenched in the industry. For those who have been retrenched, we send them for courses and training in order that they, after having found new skills, can then be re-employed in the industry, thus allowing them the opportunity to continue with their work.

    Unfortunately, Sir, for many of these older workers, a lack of skills that is solved by education and training, is only part of the problem. For many, their age and the relatively higher salary that they command make them unemployable. What can we do to ensure that these workers who have gone for training are given employment? At this moment, we recognise that there is some tension between leaving employment entirely to market forces and having employment

Column: 210

regulated to a greater extent by legislation.

    The truth of the matter is that there are many older workers who have been retrenched, and having spent time acquiring new skills, are still having difficulty finding jobs. Will the Government be prepared to consider, aside from the present scheme of helping them find jobs through an exchange run by the Manpower Ministry, more initiatives in getting these retrenched older workers back to the workforce?

The Singaporean as a member of a wider community

    The President's Speech touches on the fact that it is not enough for Singaporeans to be individually talented. Our drive towards making Singapore a better society depends very much on getting Singaporeans to vote together and having a common sense of commitment to Singapore and to one another. Here we speak of the Singapore "heartware".

    We recognise that social bonding and cohesion is an essential ingredient for the long-term survival of Singapore. In order for Singaporeans to have one heartbeat for Singapore, it is important that we continue to emphasise to all Singaporeans that they, irrespective of colour, creed, age or gender, will always have a place in this country. Our policy statements must therefore be sensitive to not creating artificial distinctions within society that unnecessarily stratify people according to categories. We divide people into the Normal and Express stream students, the gifted and non-gifted students, the EM1 and EM2 students, the overseas scholars and local scholars; or for that matter, the scholar class as opposed to the non-scholar class; and more recently, the distinction between foreign talents and local talents, and, of course, the cosmopolitans and the heartlanders. If one thinks about it, it is essentially these categories of distinction that divide people into being more capable as opposed to being less capable. How will this division, Sir, help with the bonding process that we are all trying so hard to create?

Column: 211



    While the reality of inequality in life is a fact that we must all recognise and live with, it is another to be typecast and to be constantly told, whether directly or indirectly, that one is less capable than the other. I can understand and appreciate the circumstances in which these distinctions have emerged. However, we must be mindful that in harping on this subject, we may lead to a situation of a deep divide within our society. This would surely put a strain on our social cohesion rather than reinforce it.

    We should perhaps give more emphasis to the principle that for those who are more capable, the rewards will be there for them, and more is expected of them to serve our society. For those who are not as capable, they will always be a part of Singapore, and be made to feel that they are just as wanted and appreciated for what they have contributed towards the making of this country. Here, I like the idea that we should have more emphasis on bonding between the successful Singaporeans and those who have not done as well. We must not envy or begrudge those who have succeeded. However, every Singaporean has a given right to share in the country's success. Equally, those who contribute more on taxes must not begrudge the various schemes aimed at improving the lot of the not so fortunate. After all, we must remember that it is our duty to look after the less fortunate in our society.

    Sir, we speak of an active citizenship under the Singapore 21 vision that envisages more avenues for citizens to participate in the nation's affairs, in order to tap on the widest range of views. My colleague, Mr Thomas, has also touched on this issue earlier. We want to be able to get citizens to participate in the building of Singapore, and to get them to contribute ideas so that they can understand what is at stake. In law, we have this maxim that justice must not only be done, but must be seen to be done. This principle applies equally well in our desire to want participation of our people in the policy-making process.

Column: 212



    We have the Feedback Unit and the regular dialogue sessions with our grassroots leaders. Many people have often wondered how much of the feedback that is given has been taken into consideration in the formulation of policies. No doubt, there is certain feedback which has translated itself into changes in policies and legislation. On the other hand, there has also been numerous feedback that has been perceived to have been ignored. Perhaps more can be done in this regard to convince the people that their views are taken seriously. As a simple illustration, there are many Bills in this Parliament that have been passed which have had the participation of many concerned Members. Yet, despite the input of the Members, the Bills nonetheless are immediately passed after the Second Reading. In some cases, we have had assurances from the Government that subsequent amendments to the Act will take into account the feedback. However, in some other cases, it did not appear that the feedback was taken seriously.

    Our focus on the development of people in this debate touches on the issue of the kind of civil society we want to create in Singapore. My learned colleague, the Member for Bishan-Toa Payoh GRC, has asked pertinent questions in this debate. He asked whether the people of Singapore are prepared to take responsibility for their decisions and how the Government can send clear signals on the terms of participation from the citizens.

    Sir, there are many forces at work in society. While some may like to argue for more political space within Singapore, I agree with my colleague that others may not feel as comfortable for the kind of space that is asked for, and we would be quite happy with the status quo. To those who clamour for Singapore to be a better civil society, there is a certain presumption that this is what the rest of Singaporeans want. The truth of the matter is that your HDB heartlander may not be so interested in these issues so long as the integrity of the Government of Singapore is not in doubt and the people continue to enjoy a standard and quality of life that is unparalleled anywhere in the world. What

Column: 213

makes this vocal minority think that they have a better right to impose their views on the silent majority? We must recognise that the responsibility of the Government rests in balancing the various forces at work. We must also remember that a duly elected government has the mandate of the people to do so.

    Sir, we accept that it is not always possible for the Government to agree to every issue. However, where there is indeed a constructive attempt being made to improve legislation or policies, the Government must be seen to be taking this effort more seriously.

    Finally, I would like to extend my deepest appreciation to the President for delivering the keynote Speech of the Government. No doubt, the Speech is meant to chart the course of the Government in the coming years. It has also provided us a valuable opportunity to take stock of where we are coming from and where we are heading.

    For the above reasons, Sir, I support the motion.

    Mr Low Thia Khiang (Hougang): Clarification with the Member. In his speech he mentioned that civil society may not be desirable for HDB heartlanders and the Government has a duty to balance their interests. I would like to know from him, in his view, how does civil society, as implied in his speech, come in conflict with the interest of HDB heartlanders, if the Government decides that civil society is desirable.

    Mr Sin Boon Ann: I think central to the debate on civil society is a certain perception that a civil society must entail certain values. These values are to some extent a reflection of the kind of values that is often associated with the more liberal society of the West; where there is greater freedom of speech, greater civic participation, and a more liberal media. These are the sorts of issues that one would normally associate with a civil society. Having said that, and this is consistent with the kind of debate that has emerged in recent months, the sort of

Column: 214

ideas that go into a debate for civil society need not necessarily dovetail with the kind of interests that the HDB heartlanders may have. And to that extent, therefore, it may not necessarily be the same kind of agenda that the two interest groups are pursuing.

    Mr Zulkifli Bin Baharudin (Nominated Member): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise in support of the motion and wish to express my thanks to the President for his Speech.

    I have come across many Singaporeans who, like Mr Chiam See Tong, think that the President's Speech does not contain anything new in terms of the Government's visions and policies for the future.

    Personally, I do not expect anything new nor do I think there should be one. Indeed, the economic crisis has served to adequately remind us that our current policies with regard to managing the economy, responsiveness to changes, openness and transparency of information, being pragmatic and ready to take the pain and involving our best and brightest, both in the Government and private sector, remain relevant now and in the future.

    Perhaps what is quite less understood by many Singaporeans is the fact that the changes made to the banking and financial sector, recommendations contained in the Committee on Singapore's Competitiveness and policy on foreign talent, are by any measure a major transformation and reformation of our economy and society.

    The fact that this was implemented without any accompanying violent protest and political instability that have rocked our neighbours does not make it less exciting or significant. Many have lost their jobs, suffered wage and CPF cuts. Small and medium enterprises continue to face severe challenges posed by a variety of global pressures.

    Perhaps one visible aspect during the economic crisis has been the important role the private sector has played in tandem with the Government through

Column: 215

the various committees to draw up plans to get us out of this crisis. To the Singaporeans at large, they have witnessed how collective efforts of both the Government and private sector have brought about the desired results during one of the most serious crisis experienced by Singaporeans.

    On this note, Sir, allow me to respond to the two main issues that were discussed, ie, active citizenship and social cohesion. It is a great day for me as a member of civil society to listen to Members of the House speaking in support of active citizenship. This alone demonstrates how far we have progressed in terms of developing an active people sector. This is a strong endorsement to the many people working in civil societies. Let me remind the House that civil society is not a western concept.

    However, there remain many challenges to overcome and I would like to highlight a few of them:

    One is changing mindset. In the past, it is quite common to hear of civil societies being categorised into social workers and armchair critics and social commentators who are frequently challenged for the lack of involvement in social and charitable activities. It is as if one must be involved in charitable activities before being considered as doing something for society.

    While it is clear that the ultimate objective is for the best and ablest in the society to help the less able through volunteerism, members of civil society are usually initially driven at least by enthusiasm, passion, spontaneity and idealism. Quite often, it starts with them articulating their views as many feel the need to contribute in terms of ideas and feedback. The more accessible communication channels today make it more convenient for many to make their first start by contributing ideas. The more involved and committed - perhaps prompted into action - would then participate as members of the various organisations that best suit them.

Column: 216



    Therefore, there is a need to change the mindset and to view these people, not as irritating commentators to policy makers, but perhaps as a growing and untapped pool of young idealistic citizens who can play a part in our common goal to help improve society.

    To help change this mindset, we can do a number of simple things:

    (1) have civil servants, employees of statutory boards and Government corporations to be more involved in civil society so that they can have a better appreciation of civil society and perhaps become civil society's active citizens themselves. Quite frequently, the problems of civil societies are at the operational level - with the bureaucracy;

    (2) have Government agencies involving relevant civil societies to participate in the various activities and to be invited to some of the relevant functions organised. Of course, civil societies too must reciprocate but here the common complaint is usually the unenthusiastic response from Government agencies;

    (3) civil societies themselves should start by not excluding other organisations like the CDCs and self-help groups and many other agencies as not being part of the larger family of civil society. We should not differentiate the Government sponsored civil society and independent groups as, ultimately, they both serve a common goal for our society; and

    (4) Mr J. B. Jeyaretnam talked about the fear that Singaporeans have in involving themselves in debate and public discussions. First, it must be clear to anyone intending to venture into public discussions to be prepared to be intellectually challenged, even robustly. This is to be expected. However, I do sense that some of the replies from the Government may be a bit too personal which may tend to discourage public discussion.

    Having said that, I would say that being thick-skinned must certainly be one of the necessary prerequisites of anyone intending to engage in public debate. For

Column: 217

those who feel personally slighted or rebuked, I have this to say to them, "Don't Quit" because this country was not built by quitters.

    Next, is for the Government agencies to use the strength and not weaknesses of civil societies. Quite often, civil societies are bogged down by fund-raising activities. Lack of financial and administrative resources are common complaints of civil societies. This is where greater collaboration between Government agencies and civil society can be more effective to tap their enthusiasm, commitment, network and not rely on their weaknesses for fund raising.

    Third, globalisation. Like anything else, civil societies too are affected by internationalisation and globalisation. Their values on society and environment, for example, are no longer domestic or national issues. It transcends geographical boundaries. Increasingly, civil societies will find more things in common with civil societies in other countries. There will be greater need for joint collaboration and mutual assistance. This is where civil societies in Singapore are sometimes unnecessarily disadvantaged as many exercise self restraint in obtaining assistance of financial help from other institutions overseas as they may be perceived to be promoting a foreign agenda or, worse still, become elements of other undesirable organisations.

    We need to recognise that working with foreign organisations is going to be part and parcel of a larger civil society as we become part of a global family. Therefore, we must not only be prepared to learn from others but also become active contributors ourselves to other causes in the region.

    On this note, I would like to respond to the very encouraging gestures that Simon Tay and I would like to undertake a study on "Civil Society in 21st Century Singapore". This, in our view, is an indication of how civil society can proceed and progress beyond discussion and debate. The report would address on the

Column: 218

potential contribution and personal limitation and challenges facing Singapore's young civil society. The issues that our report would address include the registration of societies, limits on speech, assembly and association, especially in public, and the role of private foundations and Government agencies in supporting civil society organisations. The report would also look at civil society in Singapore in a broader regional and international context.

    I would now like to quote from Judith Shklar an extract from the National Standards for Civics and Government:

    "Active citizens . are public meeting-goers and joiners of voluntary organisations who discuss and deliberate with others about the policies that will affect them and who serve their country not only as taxpayers and occasional soldiers, but by having a considered notion of the public good that they genuinely take to heart. The good citizen is a patriot."

    Mr Speaker, Sir, allow me to touch on another issue of social cohesion. I am prompted today to include these two issues in view of the recent incident which in my view demonstrates the fragility of a social cohesion and that each and every Singaporean has a part to play to preserve and enhance social cohesion.

    At the recent Mendaki-MUIS Tea Party to congratulate Malay-Muslim graduates from higher institutions last week, I was seated with four young Malay graduates, whom I later discovered, two of whom will be going for further education overseas. I was delighted to find out that all four of them told me their families no longer depend on them for financial contribution. This demonstrates how far sections of the Malay-Muslim society have progressed.

    However, when I asked them what would be the most difficult problem they would face when they enter working life, they remarked that the perception others have of them would be the greatest obstacle they would face and they expressed concern that they may not be given equal opportunities by employers. If the best and ablest of our society and those who have profited and benefited from our system feel pessimistic, I wonder how less successful Malay-Muslims feel.

Column: 219



    On another occasion, as a member of the Work Group on KBE, initiated by the Malay PAP MPs, we met two groups of bankers separately: one, Malay-Muslim workers in the financial sector and, two, representatives of major banks who coincidentally are all Chinese. Our discussions revealed wide differences of perceptions one has of the other.

    These are no small matters which cannot be resolved overnight but efforts must be taken quickly as part of a long and permanent process of bridging these perceptions. For a start, I have asked these bankers whether they are prepared to help Malay-Muslims in the financial sector to improve and upgrade themselves as the community is short of skilled expertise and resources to face the challenges of KBE. They are quite happy to help knowing that their efforts will go a long way towards bridging these perceptions. I must thank them for their willingness.

    On the other hand, Malay-Muslims too need to be more relevant on national and international issues and be more actively involved in the various social community organisations outside the Malay-Muslim community. Malay values of gotong-royong must be extended to include other Singaporeans. I personally know of many organisations who are desperately looking for Malay-Muslim members. Malay-Muslims must and need to respond to this.

    Finally, I would like to touch on the issue of Malays in the SAF which was touched upon by the Member for Cheng San. First, let me say that the Senior Minister's comments came from his personal experience. More significantly, our geography makes this issue a relevant and permanent one. In my view, the reaction of the community is good because it indicates that Malays care about what other Singaporeans think of them. It would be worse if Malays have not responded.

    Perhaps the only way to change perception is for Malays themselves,

Column: 220

especially those in the SAF, to continue to demonstrate their commitment through working with other Singaporeans, earning mutual respect and trust of fellow soldiers and Singaporeans. Beyond rhetoric, we need to demonstrate good deeds.

    But I must caution that it would be unwise for anyone to think that this can be solved through one dialogue session. Anyone is free to write and speak on this issue provided racial sensitivities are not breached. While Malay leaders like Encik Othman Wok and Encik Rahmat Kenap have earned the trust and confidence of the Senior Minister, I am sure there are many other younger Malays deserving of such an association. Hopefully, over time, many more will be identified. Because only then can perception change.

    Dr Teo Ho Pin (Sembawang): Mr Speaker, Sir, as a young nation with limited natural resources, Singapore has done well to position itself to be a world-class city in the world. Over the last 34 years, the Singapore Government has, through careful planning and prudent use of public funds, developed Singapore into a modern city with excellent infrastructure and amenities. Today, Singaporeans live in high quality housing, a clean and green environment and enjoy a comfortable lifestyle.

    Singapore has also made its mark of excellence in the global market. We are known in the world for our airline, SIA; our seaport, PSA; our public housing programme, HDB; and our clean and green environment. We have successfully built a positive corporate image for

Column: 221

Singapore. Today, many people are aware of the existence of Singapore. They know where Singapore is and what is Singapore like. But not many people understand Singaporeans or know what is a Singaporean. We have yet to develop a "brand name" for Singaporeans. Instead, some foreigners have negative perceptions of Singaporeans such as Singaporeans are not allowed to chew chewing gum in Singapore; Singaporeans are fined for not flushing toilets; Singaporeans are caned or jailed for any wrongdoing. These perceptions always cause embarrassment to many Singaporeans when they meet up with their foreign friends.

    We have read in the papers about the ugly Singaporean or the kiasu Singaporeans who misbehave themselves and project a bad image for Singaporeans especially when they travel overseas. If such behaviours were to propagate, we would be embarrassed to be called Singaporeans.     We must nurture Singaporeans to be caring and considerate citizens of the world. More efforts should be channelled to inject meaning into the lives of Singaporeans. Singaporeans must learn to be more "human" in a fast-changing and materialistic world. We must live life to make a difference to other people's life and that is our ultimate goal of living.

    Sir, I support the President's call for the Government to focus on people. This is a timely call for all Government departments to pay more attention to Singaporeans.     Debate resumed.

    The Minister for Manpower (Dr Lee Boon Yang): Mr Speaker, Sir, thank you for allowing me to join in the debate. I rise to speak in support of the motion standing in the name of Mr Davinder Singh.

    Sir, the President in his Address to open the Second Session of this Parliament had highlighted Government's efforts to promote life-long learning and to enhance our people's skills and capability under the Manpower 21 plan. Several hon. Members have also spoken in support of the Manpower 21 plan. I thank them for their endorsement and support for the initiatives contained in the Manpower 21 Report.

    Yesterday, Mr Lim Boon Heng, speaking about the employee share option scheme, urged caution on our companies to adopt such an approach of rewarding their employees. I think he made a valid point. We should proceed with care when adopting such new ideas. He said that one should be wary of adopting new ideas that appear to be great but their consequences are not fully known. I agree with that approach. But there are other ideas which, although new and novel, are self-evidently

Column: 228

relevant and applicable to our situation, and we should be prepared to adopt them immediately and wholeheartedly.

    I will give you an example, Sir. The latest issue of Business Week (18th October) contained a special report entitled "Learning to Lead". It described how an energy company in the US, Conoco Inc, coped with a 1998 downturn in oil price and surplus capacity within the company. The usual approach in such a situation, when your product price is going down, would have been to cut spending and to close plants, which would mean retrenching some workers. Instead, the CEO made an unusual decision. He decided to make a major investment in the company's managers. He approved a new comprehensive leadership-development programme for his senior executives. The CEO explained, "Even though oil was at $10, it was the right decision. You're going to be successful in the long term if you have good people". That was why in the worst of times, Conoco was still investing in training its people to provide good leadership, so that the company can weather the crisis and emerge more competitive and more successful. Conoco was not alone in taking this approach. According to the same Business Week report, and I quote, "Corporate America has concluded that investing in people is the way ahead."

    Sir, this is one idea that we must adopt and embrace wholeheartedly, and apply as soon as we can. And this, in fact, is what M21 is all about. It sets out a strategy or blueprint, if you like it, for Government and employers to invest in our people as a means for Singapore to stay ahead. It provides a framework for all Singaporean workers to upgrade their skills, knowledge and capabilities so as to stay relevant and to remain employable.

    Sir, the recent economic recession, though rather brief, was a timely reminder of our vulnerability. It shows how easily tens of thousands of Singaporean workers can be made redundant. Now that the crisis is largely over and the Singapore economy seems to be well on the road to recovery, it is indeed timely for us to reassess our situation.

Column: 229



    We can sit back and simply ride this wave of recovery by doing, more or less, the same, doing what we have been doing before the crisis itself. It is the easiest way out. It is the course of least resistance. But the danger of taking this approach, this pathway of least resistance, is that with increasing globalization, we would be exposed to increasing competition and, over time, our economic space will shrink. We have to seek out new opportunities and adopt a new paradigm for growth and prosperity. So, what we should do is to use this recent experience to plan for the future. Of course, we cannot precisely determine what the future will hold for us, but we can safely assume that the 1998 recession would not be the last nor would it be the worst.

    Sir, in the pre-crisis days, economic growth resulted in the creation of as many as 120,000 new jobs a year. Singaporeans were, in fact, spoilt for choice. Companies rushed to carry out "green-harvesting" exercises. University graduates were offered jobs before they actually graduated. Production workers could quit a job and walk down the street to another factory and find another job with a $50 pay increase. In fact, many jobs had to be filled by foreign workers, due to a sheer shortage of Singaporeans. In some areas, it was a shortage of suitably skilled and qualified workers; but in many other areas, it was a shortage of workers who were willing to take on the less attractive and less pleasant jobs.

    In the post-crisis days, as the economy recovers, we cannot expect the labour market to return to the conditions prevailing in 1995 to 1997. If our GDP grows at the target rate of about 5% a year, and at least half of this growth comes from productivity gains, the balance will have to come from an expansion of labour supply, to yield a net job creation of around 60,000 jobs a year. This means that we must be prepared for a lower level of job creation, even as the economy recovers and settles to its long-term growth rate of between 4-6%.

    We will have to ask ourselves what are the jobs which will support sustainable

Column: 230

economic growth over the longer term. As we move towards a knowledge-based economy, the jobs are likely to be transformed into knowledge intensive jobs. What this means is that while industries will need fewer people, these workers will be of much higher calibre, higher skilled, able to perform more valuable jobs and earn higher wages. Singaporeans must begin to prepare for these changes now.

    What would be the developments affecting jobs in the future? We think there are three developments that we must look out and be prepared for. These developments will form the backdrop and provide the challenges for us in implementing Manpower 21.

IT/Technology Based Workplace Environment

    Sir, the first is the technology-based workplace environment. There is no question that technology will reshape not only the electronic and manufacturing based industries. Every other industry and business will be affected by the use of technology. Information technology and e-commerce are just examples of how technology has been applied to improve business efficiency and customer reach.

    For example, information technology is progressively being applied in sectors such as retail, banking and insurance to dramatically expand the delivery channels and the reach towards new customers, and, of course, also to improve the service to their customers. In education, the intranet and the Internet provide opportunity to apply new learning methods which can bring a whole host of education materials to the fingertips of students. Retail staff, bank staff, insurance salesmen, as well as teachers, will all need to be prepared for such changes. Increasingly, our workers have to be IT savvy, attuned to the latest technology and comfortable with the demands of the new jobs which are being created.

    Even in traditional fields such as construction, the use of technology will result in sizeable improvements in productivity and reduction in the need for

Column: 231

low skilled foreign construction workers. Next week, my Ministry will launch the Construction 21 Report and announce new measures to transform the construction industry.

    While our new school leavers and graduates of polytechnics and universities will be well prepared for these changes and demands of new jobs, we must not forget the older workers who may not have the same skills and are in many cases hampered by their lower education. The concept of "lifelong learning" put up by the Manpower 21 Committee is designed to help mature workers learn new skills to help them to keep up with the changing job requirements. While younger entrants to the workforce will be better equipped, their stock of knowledge and skills will also get outdated in the face of technological progress. So even today's well educated younger Singaporeans must adopt a new mindset and embrace lifelong learning so as to stay employable.

New Growth Industries

    The second major development is the accelerated pace of rise and fall of companies and industries. This is the result of the unprecedented pace of technological advances and applications. To succeed and remain profitable, companies are constantly seeking new products and new services. They are always looking out for better, more productive and lower cost opportunities. Those which cannot keep up with the pace of change will soon find themselves shut out of the market. In response to this trend, restructuring will become part and parcel of business growth and survival. When companies reorganize to concentrate on their core activities or to venture into new areas, very frequently, there will be employment disruption and, in some cases, retrenchment of surplus staff. So while the demand for a people with knowledge and capabilities in growth areas will increase, other workers may well find that their skills are no longer needed. There will be a shrinking demand for their skills.

Column: 232



    For example, since 1992, the manufacturing share of employment in Singapore has declined from 29% to 21% in 1998. While demand for higher skilled technicians, engineers, computer systems analysts and product research and development workers will still grow, the demand for production and assembly workers is expected to continue to decline. Our approach to helping these workers is to equip them with new skills and help them to re-deploy to other economic sectors, such as service industries.

    Other growth sectors which will continue to create jobs for our people will include the banking, finance, communication, broadcasting and information technology sectors. In the IT sector alone, the current pool of 33,000 IT professionals is expected to grow at about 10% a year for several more years.

    To prepare for the manpower needs in the high growth sector, my Ministry is planning to launch a Strategic Manpower Conversion Programme. This is a programme whereby workers are encouraged to undergo short "conversion" courses to acquire new knowledge and skills for careers in the growth areas. For a start, my Ministry is working with NCB on a programme to convert non-IT trained workers for higher value added jobs in the growing IT sector. The scheme will be implemented early next year. We will use the experience gained from this pilot project in the IT sector and extend it to the other new growth areas so that Singaporeans can be better equipped and better prepared to take on these new jobs.

Raising skills levels and multi-skilling

    The third development is the demand for flexibility, creativity and thinking skills and also multi-skilled workers. Gone are the days when a production worker or production operator focuses on a single task on the assembly line. In a typical hi-tech manufacturing plant, whether it is in petrochemicals, semiconductors or food manufacturing, most of the actual work itself is done by machines, operated by a few highly skilled workers. These workers will have to conduct quality

Column: 233

inspection and trouble-shooting and even maintenance of the machines that are placed under their care.

    Even in traditional jobs such as in the cleaning industry, healthcare aides, hotel industry with the need for a large number of chambermaids and other backroom support staff, there is scope to raise their skills and productivity by widening the scope of such jobs through proper training. The result is to enhance the image and dignity of these jobs. This will help us in our effort to re-deploy some workers who will be made redundant as the manufacturing industry reduces its labour requirements.

    To motivate workers to undergo upgrading so that they can continue to remain employable or be redeployed to other sectors, my Ministry is developing the National Skills Recognition System (NSRS). The NSRS is a framework that will develop industry skills standards in the manufacturing and service sectors and accord national recognition to the training that meets these standards. The NSRS will enable mature workers to earn credit for what they have learnt, and provide an additional mechanism for employers to assess their employees' skills level. This system is designed to be accessible to all workers, regardless of their basic education. It will provide all workers with the opportunity for skills certification to a nationally recognized standard. This will help facilitate the gradual transition of the lower skilled segments of our workforce into the knowledge economy and encourage them to also pursue lifelong learning.

    Apart from promoting lifelong learning, training and retraining, we must also constantly examine our employment market to look for areas that can be improved and also to enhance our resilience and competitiveness. For instance, we must refine our wage system to enable companies to be more responsive to changing business conditions in good and bad times. Hence, employers should quickly adopt the monthly variable payment (MVP) system. This system was recommended by the

Column: 234

National Wages Council in May this year as a means to help companies to adapt to the changing business cycle. The monthly variable payment will in fact give companies an additional measure to adjust cost without having to retrench workers or resort to more painful wage cuts.

    We should also rationalize some of our employees' benefit system, such as the introduction of a co-pay principle for medical care. This was in fact recommended by a Tripartite Committee nearly three years ago but progress in implementation has been fairly slow. On the contrary, the civil service has already implemented this system since 1994, and has made very good progress with it. The question is: can we afford further delays in implementing a measure which will result in better allocation of health care benefits across the board and also ensure that our employers or companies do not bear an unfair share of providing such medical benefits to their employees?

    There is also the sacred cow of retrenchment benefits. A ceiling of 25 years service was introduced when the retirement age was raised to 62 years last year. However, as I mentioned earlier, the pace of change will cause companies to restructure and reorganise much more frequently in future. Companies will have to down-size when the market turns against them and when they develop new products or new services, they can then grow again. So company sizes will change. There will be frequent restructuring and reorganisation. If our retrenchment benefits are perceived by investors to be too generous and a hindrance to corporate restructuring, we may lose our attractiveness to such investors. Can we afford to pass up such opportunities because we want to preserve the present system of protecting our workers from unexpected retrenchment? Or should we recall, go back to first principle that retrenchment benefits were meant to help workers to tide over the period during which they are unemployed and looking for a new job?

    These are all very sensitive issues with tremendous impact on the state of our

Column: 235

industrial relations. But we must start to discuss these issues and build up a tripartite consensus on how we can make progress. We have already started to do so with regard to another issue concerning union representation for executives in a company. In the years ahead, we must also find equitable and mutually agreeable solutions to these other issues so that they will not hinder the effort to create jobs for our people.

Conclusion

    The new millennium will present many new opportunities to Singapore. These are opportunities which we must seize and ride on to bring us into the next phase of growth. If we are ill prepared, we will miss out on these opportunities and slide down on the competitive ladder. This will mean higher unemployment rate. We will have to live with higher unemployment rate. There will be insufficient and lower value-added jobs for our people who will end up earning lower wages and have to put up with lower standard of living.

    The transition to the new economy involves every individual. It is not confined to only the engineers and those who are highly educated. Rather, it requires the commitment, determination and effort of all Singaporeans at every level of the workforce. It requires our people to be willing to learn, to try new things, to be innovative. Whether professionals or production workers, employers or employees, the key to our ability to earn good living in the future will rest on our ability to acquire new knowledge and skills and to use these to add value to the economic effort. Individuals can choose to be overwhelmed by the changes and languish by the side, or take a proactive role to prepare for the future and ride on its opportunities.

    While the Government will provide the overall framework, the people and the private sector have to take the lead in seizing the growth and learning opportunities. Employers and workers must be

Column: 236

agile, flexible and open to various possibilities in this fast moving knowledge-based economy. The Manpower 21 strategy and programmes represent a blueprint or a road map. Workers, employers and the Government must travel along this road hand-in-hand so that we can arrive together at our common destination. The road is not straight nor smooth. It is winding, runs uphill with many obstacles along the way. We must help each other to navigate the climb and overcome the hazards on the way. Government, working with the employers, will invest, subsidize, motivate and encourage workers to upgrade their skills. Singaporeans must also make personal commitment to make full use of these opportunities to upgrade. Every worker must adopt the "lifelong learning" credo and make continuing effort to ensure his or her employability. I urge all employers and workers to join us in this exciting and rewarding journey to transform ourselves into a globally competitive workforce.

    Sir, many Members have spoken and given suggestions and made many good comments on the M21 report. I do not propose to go into the details and respond to individual comments, but let me assure all the hon. Members that my Ministry will study and consider their suggestions and comments as we implement the recommendations of the Manpower 21 Committee report.

    Sir, I support the motion.

more vibrant, we have to make full use of our human resources. The President also emphasised that we have to pay more attention to our aging population. Allow me to raise some recommendations on these issues.

We have about 300,000 senior citizens in Singapore. If all these 300,000 senior citizens were to go to the Singapore General Hospital for a medical check-up, then I am sure the hospital will be very crowded and very busy, and these old people will have problem getting there too.

    In order to make it easier for the senior citizens, I think the community and grassroots organisations can also help in this aspect. Maybe regular check-ups for the senior citizens can be conducted in the

Column: 238

community centres, say, routine checks on eyesight, blood sugar, blood pressure and cholesterol, etc. On the one hand, this will be easier for the senior citizens and, on the other hand, this will enable the grassroots organisations to participate in this very meaningful job.

    After the check-up, there should be systematic documentation on the health situation of the senior citizens. In fact, many senior citizens normally forget about the results and they do not take the necessary action to prevent the diseases. The Ministry of Health should publish a medical check-up record booklet, so that when a senior citizen goes for his check-up, the doctors or nurses will be able to record his state of health there, and this will serve as a very useful future reference for the doctors when they follow up with this senior citizen.

    Presently, in schools, every pupil has a health booklet to record his or her state of health. I hope that the Minister for Health would consider publishing a similar health booklet for the senior citizens, so that they will have a better understanding of their health.

    Secondly, providing concessions for senior citizens on public transportation. In Singapore, concession is given to our senior citizens for commuting on our public transport system. However, this concession is restricted to only off-peak hours. Recently Lianhe Zaobao conducted a survey on this matter, and about 90% of those who were interviewed felt that when the bus companies give concessions to the senior citizens, there should not be a restriction on the time they can travel. But the bus companies did not agree with the finding because they felt that the senior

Column: 239

citizens should not compete with the other commuters during the peak hours, and that it will pose some danger to the old folks. But many people feel that this is not a fair reasoning. This matter has, in fact, been argued for many years and there is still no concrete outcome. Very soon, the 20th century will come to an end. We hope that before the end of the 20th century, there should be a solution to this problem.

    If we are serious and sincere in considering this problem, I think this is a responsibility of every one of us, whether it is a Government department, the private sector, grassroots organisations or the civil groups. So long as they are involved in this problem of an aging population, they should put in a concerted effort and we should work in one heart so that we can have better results. I feel that we should deal with this matter in a more objective manner. At the moment, our transport system is very comprehensive, whether it is MRT or public buses, they are being operated very smoothly, and we have a very good public transport system. The commuters are also boarding and alighting from the buses in a very orderly manner. They have been treating the old people in a very courteous manner. It is not a big problem even if the senior citizens were to board the buses during the peak hours.

    I suggest that the relevant authority should seriously consider implementing concession rates for senior citizens even during the peak hours. Maybe we should try it for one year, and one year later we can have a review and see whether this concession, without any restricted hours, would pose any serious problem to us. citizens, and it would also provide them with more convenience. In fact, in Hong Kong, in Europe and the United States, this is very common. The senior citizens enjoy concessions without any restriction. I feel that the relevant authority should seriously consider this recommendation.

    Thirdly, housing for the senior citizens. Now we have 86% of Singaporeans living in public housing, that is, more than 200,000 senior citizens are living in HDB flats. In the new housing estates, the lifts stop at every floor. This is a very good service to the residents, particularly to the senior citizens.     The Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister and Minister for Health (Mr Chan Soo Sen) (In Mandarin): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, thank you for giving me this opportunity to speak in support of the motion in the name of Mr Davinder Singh to thank the President for his Address.     In his policy Speech, the President outlined our vision and listed the tasks ahead for us. To me, this is truly thought-provoking. He reminded me of three Chinese sayings about "ku", or hardship:

    (1) chi de ku zhong ku, fang wei ren shang ren ( ), meaning you must be able to endure utmost hardship before you can be above the others;

    (2) tong gan gong ku ( ), meaning as true friends and partners we should share in each other's comfort and hardship; and

    (3) ku jin gan lai ( ), meaning after enduring hardship, happiness will eventually come.

Column: 262



    Singapore 21 Vision is something worthy of all our people to fight and strive for. In a sense, we have no choice but to strive for it. This is because we are facing very intense competition. We are like a boat sailing against the current. We must forge ahead or else we will be driven back.

    However, to succeed, we must have strong fighting spirit. Success will not be plain sailing. There will be hardship to endure. The three sayings I quoted above are not only the trilogy for us to realise our Singapore 21 Vision, but they are also the rondo for the long-term endeavours of Singapore.

    We want to go for the knowledge-based economy. On the one hand, we have to work hard. On the other hand, we also have to constantly upgrade ourselves. So we have to keep on learning and keep on working hard. This is tough - real hardship indeed!

    This reminds me of the story of "The King and the Spider" which I read in primary school. Once upon a time, when Scotland was at war with England, the King of Scotland lost six battles successively against England. He took shelter at a broken house. There, he saw a spider making its web. When the web was half way through, the wind blew and the web was broken. The spider tried again, but the same thing happened. It kept on trying and trying, until the sixth time, yet it failed

Column: 263

again. The king who was taking shelter there said, "Poor spider, you are like me. I have also lost six battles. I do not think I should try again." But the tiny little spider refused to give up, and on the seventh time, it succeeded in completing its web. The king jumped up in joy and called up all his subordinates to prepare for a new battle. As it turned out, he won! This story tells us how we should face our failures. I asked my children whether they have read the fable. Both of them said no. We should create opportunities for children to read this kind of story. When we succeed, we have also encouragement from our friends and people to share our happiness and joy. This makes life rich, meaningful, and interesting. Column: 266

    Another problem I would like to raise is the problem raised by the Prime Minister at the National Day Rally. The issue is on

Column: 269

the use of Singlish. This is a common social phenomenon and it is a common way of communication among the ordinary citizens. Although it is not good to use adulterated English, it is, after all, a by-product of our multi-racial and multi-lingual society. It was only when I realise that some Singaporeans who speak pure English and not Singlish are also not able to speak standard English and write standard English that I begin to understand how very important it was for the Prime Minister to raise this issue of speaking standard English.

    Everyone knows that I am a Chinese-educated MP. I am unable to speak standard English. Yet, I reject the use of adulterated English, just as I do not agree with people speaking adulterated Mandarin. During my business trips overseas, whenever I hear our Singaporeans speaking the Singapore-style of Mandarin, I would try my best to stop them. Whether they are speaking English, Mandarin or Malay, the foreigners just cannot understand what they are talking. The adulterated languages of Singapore are generated because of the multi-racial environment. Most Singaporeans can understand this type of language, but the foreigners do not.

    Let me quote you an example. When I was in China, I actually heard a Singaporean speaking, "My brother kahwin liao." All Singaporeans present could understand what he was talking about. But in China, England or the United States, I am sure the people there would have no clue at all as to what he was talking about. Therefore, it is important for the Government to promote the correct usage in English, in Malay, in Mandarin. I think it is very important to our efforts to enhance our capability and then to promote a knowledge-based economy. We should not resort to the use of sub-standard language, whether it is Singlish or various forms of Mandarin. Likewise, our standard of written and spoken English cannot be compared to that of the United Kingdom and the United States of America. This does not mean to say that we cannot write grammatically correct English and speak standard English. In the promotion of the use of standard languages, besides the efforts of the school teachers, the press and the various media also play very important roles.

    Here, I would like to tell you the real-life joke concerning another Singaporean who speaks pure English. I would like to declare my interest as a publisher. In August this year, I came across this real-life incident. A pure-English speaking Singaporean and a number of journalists from the English language newspaper criticised a certain book compiled by an English author and alleged that there were "full of grammatical mistakes" in the book. They even captioned the article as: "50 language bloopers" (The Sunday Times, 1st August 1999). As a reader, my first impression would be that the report and criticism by this pure-English speaking Singaporean and the journalists from the English language newspaper, because my standard of English is not as high as theirs, must be correct. I am sure many, many Singaporeans must have believed that the newspaper report was accurate.

    However, upon consultation with this English author himself, I realise that the criticism by the English newspaper on the grammar taught in this book was not quite correct. This illustrates the point that the English-speaking Singaporeans can sometimes regard correct grammatical usage as being wrong usage, and treat some wrong usage as correct, and then launch an attack openly. A reader wrote to the Consumers Association of Singapore (CASE) and complained about wrong grammar being used in the book. She doubted the identity of the author, and even telephoned the publishers to send a punitive expedition against them. What I do not understand is why is it that she herself could not differentiate between the correct grammatical usage and the wrong usage, yet she behaved as though she

Column: 271

was having justice on her side. Why can they not be like the Lianhe Zaobao in hiring a panel or a high-quality language specialist to authenticate the English used in their reports. So from this incident, I learn the importance of the Prime Minister's insistence of speaking standard English. If we do not turn this around and correct the mistake, then we would be criticised by the foreigners that the standard of English here is very poor and it would be difficult for Singapore to make it to the list of globalised international cosmopolitan cities. Just as this English author was telling me, he was surprised that the standard of English in Singapore has dropped so dramatically over the last few years. There is nothing I could say about it.

    Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, Singaporeans have very good linguistic abilities. Many Singaporeans can speak many languages. However, they are generalists and not specialists.
